 do. Even if not *supposed* to. Because when I "try"

You could log it, so that you know a given problem has occurred, then
=
you could look at the resons that caused the error to fix the bug.  But
you=
 should then let the error filter up the chain to be handled by the
correct=
 error handler, or even halt the JVM process if it comes to that.

> For ex=
emple, if there is a classpath problem preventing me to 
> do X(), I want t=
o catch the NoClassDefFoundError, log the 
> error, and invoke my recovery =
strategy (msg to user, 
> alternate method, etc..), Not let the error go al=
l the way to 
> the top and possibly stop some important top-level task (or=
 
> worse the entire jvm process).

In this example, I would not catch Thro=
wable, then.  I would catch
NoClassDefFoundError.

The only place where I /=
may/ catch Throwable explicitly, is at the very
top of the call stack (main=
(), or some run() method), where I log the
error before gracefully shutting=
 down, or start some other recovery
strategy.  However, this should only be=
 done when a recovery strategy is
available.  What do you do in the case of=
 an OutOfMemoryError? (There
